ENTRY.SYNOPSIS: Radial profiles of imaging data in Sherpa (CIAO contributed package).

DESC.PARA: The sherpa_contrib.profiles module provides routines to create radial profile plots of imaging data and fits in Sherpa, and is provided as part of the CIAO contributed scripts package.
The module can be loaded into Sherpa by saying either of:
DESC.VERBATIM: from sherpa_contrib.profiles import * from sherpa_contrib.all import *
DESC.PARA: where the second form loads in all the Sherpa contributed routines, not just the profiles module.
The profiles module currenly provides the following routines:

TABLE.CAPTION: Plot a radial or elliptical profile

ROW.DATA: Plot a radial or elliptical profile of imaging data.
Plot a profile of the fit.
Plot a profile of the fit and residuals.
Plot a profile of the fit and residuals (units of sigma).
Plot a profile of the model.
Plot a profile of the source.
Plot a profile of the residuals.
Plot a profile of the residuals (units of sigma).

TABLE.CAPTION: Create a radial or elliptical profile

ROW.DATA: create the data used by prof_data()
create the data used by prof_fit()
create the data used by prof_model()
create the data used by prof_source()
create the data used by prof_resid()
create the data used by prof_delchi()

DESC.PARA: See the ahelp file for the routine and the contributed scripts page for further information.

ADESC.title: Changes in the scripts 4.15.1 (January 2023) release
ADESC.PARA: The routines have been updated to account for Sherpa plotting updates.

ADESC.title: Changes in the scripts 4.11.4 (2019) release
ADESC.PARA: The radial-profile plots will now be created in Matplotlib if the plot_pkg setting of your ~/.sherpa.rc file is set to pylab.

ADESC.title: CHANGES IN THE DECEMBER 2010 RELEASE
ADESC.PARA: The routines in the module have been updated to support source expressions created using the set_full_model() command introduced in Sherpa 4.2 release 2.

PARA.title: Improved behavior when used with un-filtered data

ADESC.PARA: The code has been updated so as not to require a rmin value when used with data with no spatial filters applied.
